text.text: How do I identify different facility types in ZOLL Billing?

text: ZOLL Billing supports Medicare modifiers that identify certain facility types. These modifiers enable your system to quickly identify a pick up / drop off location type in order to determine payment.

text.text: What is the purpose of assigning modifiers to facility types in ZOLL Billing?

text: Modifiers are used to quickly identify a pick up / drop off location type in order to determine payment. For example, Medicare will not pay providers to drop off a certain locations such as a physicians office. While Medicare does not pay for this service, many payers will so ZOLL Billing provides modifiers in addition to the Medicare list.

text.text: Can you explain the significance of Medicare modifiers in facility billing?

text: Medicare modifiers enable your system to quickly identify a pick up / drop off location type in order to determine payment. For example, Medicare will not pay providers to drop off a certain locations such as a physicians office. While Medicare does not pay for this service, many payers will so ZOLL Billing provides modifiers in addition to the Medicare list.

text.text: Which facility types in ZOLL Billing do not have an assigned modifier?

text: There are three facility types that do not have an assigned modifier, Other, Pharmacy, and Dialysis Center. If the facility type has NO MODIFIER ASSIGNED then the system will not automatically enter a modifier on the Charges page. If the facility you selected is assigned to one of these facility types, you must manually add a modifier to the charges before you submit the claim or change the facility to a different facility type.

text.text: What should I do if a facility type has no modifier assigned?

text: If the facility type has NO MODIFIER ASSIGNED then the system will not automatically enter a modifier on the Charges page. If the facility you selected is assigned to one of these facility types, you must manually add a modifier to the charges before you submit the claim or change the facility to a different facility type.

text.text: How do I assign a facility type when creating a new facility?

text: The facility type you select will determine the modifiers that display on the Charges page. When you are done, click Save.

text.text: What steps should I follow to change the type of an existing facility?

text: To change the type of an existing facility, you can follow these steps: 1. On the navigation bar, click **Facilities**. 2. Click the **All facilities** tab and scroll through until you find the facility name. 3. Click the facility name. 4. On the right-side of the page, click **Edit**. 5. Click the **Designation** field and select a new type from the list. 6. Click **Save changes**.

text.text: Where can I find the list of modifiers for facility types in ZOLL Billing?

text:
The list of modifiers for facility types in ZOLL Billing can be found in the **Modifier** table. The table is located on the **Charges** page. The **Modifier** table displays the following information:

* **Modifier** - The modifier code.
* **Description** - A description of the modifier.
* **Modifier Type** - The type of modifier.
* **Modifier Status** - The status of the modifier.
* **Modifier Value** - The value of the modifier.

To view the list of modifiers for facility types, you can follow these steps:

1. On the navigation bar, click **Charges**.
2. Click the **All charges** tab.
3. Click the **Modifier** tab.

The list of modifiers for facility types will be displayed in the **Modifier** table.

text.text: Are all facility types associated with a modifier in ZOLL Billing?

text: There are three facility types that do not have an assigned modifier: Other, Pharmacy, and Dialysis Center. If the facility you selected is assigned to one of these facility types, you must manually add a modifier to the charges before you submit the claim or change the facility to a different facility type.

text: Modifiers enable your system to quickly identify a pick up / drop off location type in order to determine payment. For example, Medicare will not pay providers to drop off a certain locations such as a physicians office.

text.text: How do modifiers appear on the Claim page in ZOLL Billing?

text: Modifiers appear on the Claim page in ZOLL Billing under the **Payer** tab.

text.text: What does the designation "NULL - NO MODIFIER ASSIGNED" indicate for certain facility types?

text: The designation "NULL - NO MODIFIER ASSIGNED" indicates that the facility type does not have a modifier assigned to it.

text.text: Is it possible to manually add modifiers to charges for facilities with no assigned modifier?

text: Yes, it is possible to manually add modifiers to charges for facilities with no assigned modifier. However, you must do this manually before you submit the claim.

text.text: Why is it important to ensure that the correct facility type and modifier are selected?

text: The facility type you select determines the modifier that displays on the charges page. There are three types with no modifiers, Other, Diagnostic/Therapeutic Site, and Pharmacy. If you assign one of these three types to the claim, the system will not automatically enter a modifier on the Charges page. You will need to do that manually before you submit the claim.

text.text: What information does the Incident Details tab display on the Claim page?

text:
The Incident Details tab displays the following information on the Claim page:

* NEMSIS (readable) link
* Signatures & attachments
* Coordination of benefits
* Charges

text.text: Can you explain the significance of modifiers in relation to the Incident Details tab?

text: The modifiers display on the Claim page under the Incident Details tab.

text.text: How do modifiers assist in accurately documenting incident details for billing purposes?

text: Modifiers are used to accurately document incident details for billing purposes. They are used to identify the type of service that was provided, the location where the service was provided, and the patient's condition. Modifiers can also be used to indicate that the service was provided in an emergency situation or that the patient was a Medicare beneficiary.
